comments.commentBody:
That is if you do not take into account the low labor participation rate,
the decimation of the rural land market, and the rotten infrastructure --
driven on any Colorado roads lately?

If that is great, then 'bad' would be along the lines of Somalia.
Dude... Iraq is Cheney's disaster. Get your facts right.
You forgot Venezuela, Argentina, Iran, Guatemala and Haiti.
Keep at it. We're all getting more of the "knowledge" you suggest. The more we learn, the more Motmonism looks like a cult run by a tax free multinational.

I don't see the liberal-conservative distinction.  Telling a person that they can't discriminate on the basis of race or sexual orientation is not telling someone what to think - it's telling them that certain behavior in unacceptable.  You can think some race is inferior if you choose, but you can't refuse service to members of that race.  Conservatives love to tell people that their behavior is immoral, particularly in area of sex.

David,

Some might think it is vicious to be expelled from one's Church for advocating reform.

I maintain that organized religion has done the cause of true spiritual belief a great disservice.

Many if not most wars throughout history have been waged for religion. Millions have died as a result.

Critical analysis and spiritual belief are akin, but religion thinks otherwise. Religion often stomps out the question with the questioner.

Any truth can withstand critical analysis. Why do Church leaders think so little of their beliefs that they won't subject them to discussion?

Civilization and the old order isn't always correct. Slavery was a pillar of civilization, supported by the Bible, until people stopped to question it.

I think instead people are worried about losing the cover religion gives to their biases about gender, sexual orientation and race.

I hope you don't consider my reply vicious. They are simply a counter view.

I would guess then you would say that had she been around in the late '60's and worked to remove the ban on black priests, or in the 1890's had she worked against polygamy, you'd been good with her getting kicked out in either of those cases, too.

Just because she is not the same LDS woman as you are does not mean she should be excommunicated. We have many members who have commit sins far greater than lobbying for female priests, and they are not excommunicated. You can disagree with her message, but the punishment does not fit the crime. It is a bully tactic to avoid the conversation about women in the church. I think we do an injustice to silence her.
Not really. The Catholic Church has a long and rich tradition of burning people at the stake that don't agree.

Dear Dr. Harrison,

I fear you have not run the numbers on applying sail power to ocean-going ships of modern size.

The largest sail-powered ships ever were the five-masted barques of the early 20th Century. The largest of which I have data was the square-rigger France II, of 6255 tons displacement.

This is a minnow compared to any modern cargo ship.

A container ship of less than 100,000 tons displacement is simply uneconomical at present.

Very Large Crude Carriers, VLCC class oil tankers, routinely top 1,000,000 tons displacement these days.

Take pencil and paper and try to calculate how much sail area it would take to add even a fraction of a knot to the speed of such a monster.

Consider, too, that all such vessels now cruise at average speeds much higher than the average surface wind speeds on the ocean. All ocean sailers know that there is much more often too little wind than too much. Explain, please, how a ship going 30 knots is going to get drive out of an intermittent wind blowing from 0 to 7 knots out of the wrong direction. These are not skimming wind-surfers we are talking about but deep displacement ships.

I think your prediction, "that sails will start reappearing on ocean-going ships as the cost of fuel goes up" is not well founded in economics. Much more likely that, If the cost of fuel goes up, the cost of shipping cargo will go up to cover it.

I am a Mormon... and she is welcome to come by any time for cookies and milk.  I will help her in any way I can and love her and support her, so that she can regain her testimony and return in good standing.  This won't happen though... not by my choice, but by hers.  She is not interested in returning... excommunication was by her design.  How many more women will she convince to leave their faith?  I suspect some, but not as many as you can count on your hands and feet.
I'm sure they do,

Rights are not the sole bastion of any one political group. And her right to preach is not at issue here. The church is telling HER what to think. They kicked her out for expressing her views, something you say you advocate. This is a separate issue. She has been excommunicated because she has her own opinions. So in your analogy the LDS are Liberals??
But look at all the self-congratulation you're awarded!

James, in case you hadn't noticed, congress has, to date, done absolutely nothing to control CO2 emissions or curb global warming, largely thanks to obstructionist extremists in the Republican Party. Hence the only remaining option for getting climate change under control and saving our skins is through executive authority and regulatory action.

Oh dear. What to do about folks like Miner49er, and other flat-earthers, who are in complete denial, unable to understand that the overwhelming weight of scientific evidence has proven them wrong, or simply too biased to render a useful opinion? Sadly, there is not much to do other than educate educate educate. Eventually truth prevails
The usual nonsense.  Reducing these emissions will reduce the costs of remediating their effects.  Much higher costs for the consumers.
In the mid-1960's when I lived on the Island and worked in NYC, at the end of the day, riding the LIRR eastward, I would regularly find soot in a tissue used to blow my nose.

A species thriving, and having lived through zero sea ice in times past, no sea ice at all, they thrived then as now:

http://polarbearscience.com/2014/05/30/iucn-polar-bear-specialist-group-...

http://www.thegwpf.org/new-study-polar-bears-survived-previous-warm-peri...

They look so robust and healthy, what an amazing animal, with or without ice they do very well indeed:

http://www.thegwpf.org/new-study-polar-bears-survived-previous-warm-peri...

As the ice is now in its rebound back to what modern 'science' considers 'normal', and as the globe fails to warm, these amazing bears should continue to do very well.

PPACA was intended to restack the health care deck for private corporations. Obama's health reformer Nancy-Ann DeParle came from private equity and returned to private equity, co-founding Consonant Capital which focuses on health care acquisitions. Her financial disclosures never showed any residual private equity investments, yet years later she received distributions from private equity sales of healthcare affiliates. PEUReport has that story.

The fish rots from the head down. Congress is especially odious.

Clearly, debt can create psychological barriers that go beyond mere dollars and cents. But having read the research (and having had about $25,000 in student debt myself), I would say that $20,000 is not so much, from a purely economic standpoint, to prevent most people from getting a good start in life. It's not as if people need to repay that $20,000 quickly in most cases. And having a couple thousand dollars in annual debt payments is vastly preferable to not having a college education in today's economy.

In an allegedly upwardly mobile society, 20K in debt is plenty to stop someone on an average salary from being able to have emergency savings, open retirement accounts, and/or save to purchase property. God forbid the kid also needs to buy a car coming out of school. Although the data in this study is important, the conclusion doesn't match up - one doesn't need 50K in debt to be underwater. One only needs to be coming from a lower middle class family with limited ability to continue to support young adults.

Why is that a problem?  Does anyone seriously think that this fund would even exist but for the actions of the plaintiffs' lawyers (especially the one who uncovered the part switch deception)?  That being the case, why shouldn't the lawyers get paid?

Well you would have air bags, but when the car is switched off the air bags are disabled, the power to them is turned off. That is a very different kettle of fish than turning the car off because GM did not want to pay for a recall. And it depends on what caused you to run out of gas. Modern cars warn you, limiting the liability of the manufacturer. Not just with the level, but warning lights.

How much you can steer or brake depends on the size of the car and how strong you are. But the brakes won't work for more than a few seconds after the engine stops turning. You can steer a little more but it is very difficult.

Your gas tank gauge fails
Because of that you run out of gas while at speed.
Since your engine is not running you have no power steering or power brakes.
Question: Can you steer and stop the car?
Question: If you can't whose fault is it?

What should be done about those lawyers who tried to cover things up as damage control and not even tell top management about htis.  They put people's lives at a value no better than the unit cost of the defective ignition. What did they know and when did they know it? I'm sure this tragedy bristles with severe ethical violations of the attorneys involved that should earn them disbarment, if not criminal prosecution.  Where is the Michigan State Bar in all of this?
